title: How to Make Apple and Raspberry Crumble

steps.headline: Preheat the oven to 350 °F (177 °C).
steps.description: If you're short on time, you can set it to 375 degrees Fahrenheit.

steps.headline: Stir the topping together.
steps.description: Add the oats, flour, brown sugar, and salt to a bowl. Add the nuts. You can also substitute another nut or leave the walnuts out altogether.

steps.headline: Use your hands or a pastry blender to blend in the butter.
steps.description: You're looking to make rough crumbles. Set the bowl aside.

steps.headline: Mix the filling together.
steps.description: Toss the apples, raspberries, flour, vanilla, and spices in a bowl. You can also substitute frozen raspberries for fresh.

steps.headline: Butter the baking dish.
steps.description: Liberally butter a 2-quart dish with softened butter. Use a paper towel or a butter wrapper to spread the butter around the pan. You can also use individual ramekins.

steps.headline: Spoon the filling in the dish or dishes.
steps.description: If you're using ramekins, be sure to divvy up the filling equally. Cut the butter into small cubes, and place it in dots across the top of the filling.

steps.headline: Sprinkle the topping onto the filling.
steps.description: You may need to squeeze it to get it spread out properly.

steps.headline: Bake for an hour at 350 degrees Fahrenheit.
steps.description: If you set the oven to 375 degrees, check it at 40 minutes instead. The topping should be browned, and the fruit should be bubbling.

steps.headline: Heat the milk on the stove.
steps.description: To a thick-bottomed saucepan, add the milk and sugar. Slice the vanilla bean lengthwise, and scrape out the vanilla bean caviar with a knife. Add it to the milk, too. Throw the bean in the pot, as well. If you don't want to shell out the cash for a vanilla bean, you can substitute a teaspoon of vanilla extract. You can also increase the sugar to 1/2 a cup if you want a sweeter sauce.

steps.headline: Mix two tablespoons of sugar with the egg yolks.
steps.description: Use a big bowl. With a whisk, thoroughly beat the eggs. You can add an additional egg yolk for a richer sauce. Egg whites can be frozen for future use. You can freeze them in a small container or separate them out into a ice cube tray, then remove them to a plastic bag. Just be sure to write the date on them, as you should only keep them for about a year.

steps.headline: Temper the eggs.
steps.description: Slowly pour in some of the hot milk into the eggs. Whisk as you go. You want to raise the temperature of the eggs without scrambling them.

steps.headline: Dump the mixture back into the saucepan.
steps.description: Heat over medium heat until it thickens. Stir it constantly. When it is thick enough, it will coat the back of a spoon, and you'll be able to run your finger through the sauce on the spoon without it filling in the line.

steps.headline: Add the rum.
steps.description: Once the mixture has cooled a little, add the rum. The rum is optional, but it adds a depth of flavor.

steps.headline: Strain the sauce.
steps.description: Use a fine mesh sieve to strain the sauce into an airtight container. Cool the container over ice. Cover the container with a lid or with plastic wrap to prevent a skin from forming on the top.

steps.headline: Keep it in the refrigerator.
steps.description: You can keep the sauce in the fridge for about 5 days.

text: Making Apple and Raspberry Crumble Preheat the oven to 350 °F (177 °C). If you're short on time, you can set it to 375 degrees Fahrenheit. Stir the topping together. Add the oats, flour, brown sugar, and salt to a bowl. Add the nuts. You can also substitute another nut or leave the walnuts out altogether. Use your hands or a pastry blender to blend in the butter. You're looking to make rough crumbles. Set the bowl aside. Mix the filling together. Toss the apples, raspberries, flour, vanilla, and spices in a bowl. You can also substitute frozen raspberries for fresh. Butter the baking dish. Liberally butter a 2-quart dish with softened butter. Use a paper towel or a butter wrapper to spread the butter around the pan. You can also use individual ramekins. Spoon the filling in the dish or dishes. If you're using ramekins, be sure to divvy up the filling equally. Cut the butter into small cubes, and place it in dots across the top of the filling. Sprinkle the topping onto the filling. You may need to squeeze it to get it spread out properly. Bake for an hour at 350 degrees Fahrenheit. If you set the oven to 375 degrees, check it at 40 minutes instead. The topping should be browned, and the fruit should be bubbling. Making Custard Sauce Heat the milk on the stove. To a thick-bottomed saucepan, add the milk and sugar. Slice the vanilla bean lengthwise, and scrape out the vanilla bean caviar with a knife. Add it to the milk, too. Throw the bean in the pot, as well. If you don't want to shell out the cash for a vanilla bean, you can substitute a teaspoon of vanilla extract. You can also increase the sugar to 1/2 a cup if you want a sweeter sauce. Mix two tablespoons of sugar with the egg yolks. Use a big bowl. With a whisk, thoroughly beat the eggs. You can add an additional egg yolk for a richer sauce. Egg whites can be frozen for future use. You can freeze them in a small container or separate them out into a ice cube tray, then remove them to a plastic bag. Just be sure to write the date on them, as you should only keep them for about a year. Temper the eggs. Slowly pour in some of the hot milk into the eggs. Whisk as you go. You want to raise the temperature of the eggs without scrambling them. Dump the mixture back into the saucepan. Heat over medium heat until it thickens. Stir it constantly. When it is thick enough, it will coat the back of a spoon, and you'll be able to run your finger through the sauce on the spoon without it filling in the line. Add the rum. Once the mixture has cooled a little, add the rum. The rum is optional, but it adds a depth of flavor. Strain the sauce. Use a fine mesh sieve to strain the sauce into an airtight container. Cool the container over ice. Cover the container with a lid or with plastic wrap to prevent a skin from forming on the top. Keep it in the refrigerator. You can keep the sauce in the fridge for about 5 days.
